parts.text: Hello my name is Lynn Loxton and I am going to have a
conversation with or will Wagner for the simple
lives and Oral History Project at the New York Public Library
It is February the fourth and this is being recorded at New
York City. Now or what would you like to tell me a little bit about
yourself
. OK I'm going to begin again I was born
in April twenty one thousand thirty one sort of the middle of the
Great Depression. It's only right that all the
regulations I give you my father always was
partial to my brother and I think this really affected my
life. As an example
. One day when I was about four or five my brother and I were playing
and we had a long board about six feet long and we had a
sledgehammer we weren't really doing much with it and we had to go in.
So we carried the back alley. My brother was carrying a
sledgehammer. I was carrying the longboard on my
shoulder which accidentally touched instead
he ran off saying that I hit a sledgehammer which he was carrying
. My father later
started beating me saying I shouldn't lie. Eventually I told
him all right. You tell me what you want me to say and I'll say it.
Well at the time he figured out I was telling the truth
and then we came down he said
to my brother I want to hit you
but I won't because it doesn't do any good I said I know you won't.
That was just one little incident. There were many many more.
My brother always was taken with my father somewhere it would travel
. My father and I didn't get to
go. So that was a basic point in my life
. He apologized and I
was about thirty five or so he said he was sorry and he asked for my forgiveness
. That's a long time ago. Anyway that
was one of the things that in my life.
As I grew up while I
was in high school. My father fell off
a ladder and got temporarily disabled so I quit high
school in the first year of high school.
I talked to a counselor It was absolutely useless
. He was never even mentioned the fact that an
education is important and my family didn't know
because my father went to fifth grade and my mother
graduated grammar school and then went to work. Her family had no sense of an
education but at that time people weren't
educating women so much today.
Well. Then I started working
my first jobs were like that first job was cutting
material except material for them along with
quills which was boring and challenging
and then I got into a job where I took care of stock in a curtain
company for a while and
then I quit and took a job in a place
where they made napalm and color and I worked there for a couple
months. And then I took a job in
assembly for two weeks I worked as a dishwasher
which I learned much interesting that works for me
and I took a job an electric plant.
They produce electric motors and gearboxes and I worked there for
quite a few years. It was at that time
that I met a girl and
I got married.
And then I got a job as a licensed fireman slice and
to take care of a power plant and that
was pretty good job at that point.
Things weren't going so well I lost my first I was in one thousand nine hundred eighty
seven so I met this girl
and we got married. That was in one thousand and fifty three
That was a little before I lost my eye when I lost my

fifty eight. When I
